DESC.Contact Network:
The <ansired>Contact Network</ansired> graph model describes all social interactions:
  - Nodes represent individuals in the population
  - Edges represent all interactions across which the pathogen can transmit
  - Currently, FAVITES-Lite only supports static (i.e., unchanging) contact networks
DESC.Seed Selection:
The <ansired>Seed Selection</ansired> model describes how to select "seed" individuals
(i.e., individuals infected at the start of the simulation).
DESC.Transmission Network:
The <ansired>Transmission Network</ansired> compartmental model describes how
the pathogen propagates along the contact network.

m.DESC: Number of edges attached from new nodes to existing nodes

Barabasi-Albert (BA).DESC:
The <ansired>Barabasi-Albert (BA)</ansired> model is an algorithm for generating undirected
random scale-free networks using a preferential attachment mechanism.
PROP: The total number of edges is: <ansired>m</ansired>(<ansired>n</ansired>-<ansired>m</ansired>)

m1.DESC: Number of nodes in each of the two complete subgraphs

m2.DESC: Number of nodes in the path connecting the two complete subgraphs

Barbell.DESC:
A <ansired>barbell</ansired> graph is an undirected graph composed of two complete graphs,
each with <ansired>m1</ansired> nodes, connected by a path of <ansired>m2</ansired> nodes.
PROP: The total number of nodes is: 2<ansired>m1</ansired> + <ansired>m2</ansired>
The total number of edges is: <ansired>m1</ansired>(<ansired>m1</ansired>-1) + <ansired>m2</ansired> + 1

Complete.DESC:
A <ansired>complete</ansired> graph is a simple undirected graph in which every
pair of distinct vertices is connected by a unique edge.
PROP: The total number of edges is: <ansired>n</ansired> choose 2 = <ansired>n</ansired>(<ansired>n</ansired>-1)/2
The degree of every node (and thus also the average degree) is: <ansired>n</ansired>-1

Cycle.DESC:
A <ansired>cycle</ansired> graph is an undirected graph that consists of a single cycle.
In other words, the vertices are connected in a closed chain.
PROP: When <ansired>n</ansired> > 2, the number of edges is: <ansired>n</ansired>

Empty.DESC:
An <ansired>empty</ansired> graph is a graph that does not have any edges.

Note that you very likely do not want to use this for epidemic simulations
(as there will not be any edges across which the pathogen can transmit).

p.DESC: Probability of existence of an edge

Erdos-Renyi (ER).DESC:
The <ansired>Erdos-Renyi (ER)</ansired> model is an undirected graph model in which
each of the <ansired>n</ansired> choose 2 possible edges have probability <ansired>p</ansired> of existing.
PROP: The degree distribution is: Binomial(<ansired>n</ansired>-1, k)

k.DESC: Number of nearest neighbors to connect to

p.DESC: Probability of adding a new edge

Newman-Watts-Strogatz (NWS).DESC:
The <ansired>Newman-Watts-Strogatz (NWS)</ansired> model is an undirected graph model as follows:
  1. Start with a ring of <ansired>n</ansired> nodes
  2. Connect each node with its <ansired>k</ansired> nearest neighbors
  3. For each edge (u,v) in the ring, add a new random edge (u,w) with probability <ansired>p</ansired>
PROP: The number of edges in the connected ring is: <ansired>nk</ansired>/2
The number of newly added edges is: Binomial(<ansired>nk</ansired>/2, <ansired>p</ansired>)

Path.DESC:
A <ansired>path</ansired> graph (or linear graph) is an undirected graph whose nodes can be ordered in a line,
and there exists an edge between every adjacent pair of nodes.

k.DESC: Number of nearest neighbors to connect to

Ring Lattice.DESC:
A <ansired>ring lattice</ansired> graph is an undirected graph in which
every node has an edge to each of its <ansired>k</ansired> neighbors.

Edge-Weighted.DESC:
The probability that an individual is chosen to be a seed
is weighted by the degree of that individual.

Uniform.DESC: Individuals are selected with equal probability.

MS-MIS.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIS (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

MS-MIS_MIS.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIS induced by neighbors in MIS

MS-MIS_MIA.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIS induced by neighbors in MIA

MS-MIS_FIS.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIS induced by neighbors in FIS

MS-MIS_FIA.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIS induced by neighbors in FIA

MS-MIA.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIA (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

MS-MIA_MIS.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIA induced by neighbors in MIS

MS-MIA_MIA.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIA induced by neighbors in MIA

MS-MIA_FIS.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIA induced by neighbors in FIS

MS-MIA_FIA.DESC: The transition rate MS -> MIA induced by neighbors in FIA

FS-FIS.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIS (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

FS-FIS_MIS.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIS induced by neighbors in MIS

FS-FIS_MIA.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIS induced by neighbors in MIA

FS-FIS_FIS.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIS induced by neighbors in FIS

FS-FIS_FIA.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIS induced by neighbors in FIA

FS-FIA.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIA (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

FS-FIA_MIS.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIA induced by neighbors in MIS

FS-FIA_MIA.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIA induced by neighbors in MIA

FS-FIA_FIS.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIA induced by neighbors in FIS

FS-FIA_FIA.DESC: The transition rate FS -> FIA induced by neighbors in FIA

Hethcote and Yorke (1984).DESC:
The <ansired>Hethcote and Yorke (1984)</ansired> model for gonorrhea has 8 states:
  - MA and FA: Male/Female Abstinent
  - MS and FS: Male/Female Susceptible
  - MIS and FIS: Male/Female Symptomatic Infected
  - MIA and FIA: Male/Female Asymptomatic Infected

The following transitions are possible:
  - MA -> MS and FA -> FS (nodal)
  - MS -> MA and FS -> FA (nodal)
  - MS -> MIA and FS -> FIA (induced by MIA/MIS/FIA/FIS or outside)
  - MS -> MIS and FS -> FIS (induced by MIA/MIS/FIA/FIS or outside)
  - MIA -> MS and FIA -> FS (nodal)
  - MIS -> MS and FIS -> FS (nodal)

S-A_A.DESC: The transition rate S -> A induced by neighbors in A

S-A_I.DESC: The transition rate S -> A induced by neighbors in I

S-I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I induced by neighbors in I

A-I.DESC: The transition rate A -> I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

A-I_I.DESC: The transition rate A -> I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Alert-Infected-Susceptible (.DESC:
The <ansired>Susceptible-Alert-Infected-Susceptible (SAIS)</ansired> model has three states:
  - S: Susceptible
  - A: Alert
  - I: Infected

The following transitions are possible:
  - S -> A (nodal or induced by A or I)
  - S -> I (induced by I or outside)
  - A -> I (induced by I or outside)
  - I -> S (nodal)

S-E.DESC: The transition rate S -> E (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

S-E_I.DESC: The transition rate S -> E induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Removed (SE.DESC:
The <ansired>Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Removed (SEIR)</ansired> model has four states:
  - S: Susceptible
  - E: Exposed
  - I: Infected
  - R: Removed

The following transitions are possible:
  - S -> E (induced by I or outside)
  - E -> I (nodal)
  - I -> R (nodal)

S-I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Infected (SI).DESC:
The <ansired>Susceptible-Infected (SI)</ansired> model has two states:
  - S: Susceptible
  - I: Infected

The following transition is possible:
  - S -> I (induced by I or outside)

S-I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Infected-Removed (SIR).DESC:
The <ansired>Susceptible-Infected-Removed (SIR)</ansired> model has three states:
  - S: Susceptible
  - I: Infected
  - R: Removed

The following transitions are possible:
  - S -> I (induced by I or outside)
  - I -> R

S-I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S -> I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible (SIS).DESC:
The <ansired>Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible (SIS)</ansired> model has two states:
  - S: Susceptible
  - I: Infected

The following transitions are possible:
  - S -> I (induced by I or outside)
  - I -> S
